title: Certified Flight Registered Nurse (CFRN) Exam Practice Questions
description: Comprehensive CFRN practice questions organized by BCEN Examination Content Outline categories

questions.stem: A patient presents with the following Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) values: pH 7.28, Partial Pressure of Arterial Carbon Dioxide (PaCO2) 55 mmHg, HCO3 24 mEq/L. What is the PRIMARY acid-base disturbance?
questions.rationale: This ABG shows respiratory acidosis. The pH is acidotic (<7.35), and the PaCO2 is elevated (>45 mmHg) indicating the respiratory system is the cause. The HCO3 is normal (22-26 mEq/L), meaning there is no metabolic compensation yet.

questions.stem: Which formula correctly calculates the anion gap?
questions.rationale: The correct anion gap formula is (Na+) - (Cl- + HCO3-). Normal anion gap is 12 ± 4 mEq/L. An elevated anion gap (≥16) indicates metabolic acidosis with unmeasured anions (MUDPILES).

questions.stem: For every 0.10 change in pH, how much does the potassium level change in the OPPOSITE direction?
questions.rationale: For every 0.10 change in pH, potassium changes approximately 0.6 mEq/L in the OPPOSITE direction. Critical in Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) where acidosis causes hyperkalemia.

questions.stem: What is the relationship between End-Tidal CO2 (ETCO2) and pH when ventilation changes?
options: A) 10 mmHg ETCO2 change = 0.04 pH change in same direction
B) 10 mmHg ETCO2 change = 0.08 pH change in opposite direction
C) 5 mmHg ETCO2 change = 0.08 pH change in same direction
D) 20 mmHg ETCO2 change = 0.08 pH change in opposite direction
questions.rationale: For every 10 mmHg change in ETCO2/PaCO2, the pH changes approximately 0.08 in the OPPOSITE direction. Increased CO2 causes acidosis (lower pH).

questions.stem: What formula is used to calculate bicarbonate replacement for metabolic acidosis?
options: B) 0.1 × body weight (kg) × negative base excess
questions.rationale: The formula for bicarbonate replacement is 0.1 × body weight (kg) × (-BE) = mEq of bicarbonate needed.

questions.stem: Which mnemonic is used to predict difficult bag-valve-mask ventilation?
questions.rationale: HEAVEN predicts difficult Bag-Valve-Mask (BVM) ventilation: Hypoxemia, Excess body weight, Aspiration risk, Ventilation problems (asthma/Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)), Elderly (>55), No teeth/decreased muscle tone.

questions.stem: What does LEMON stand for in airway assessment?
options: A) Larynx, Edema, Mandible, Obstruction, Neck
B) Look, Evaluate 3-3-2, Mallampati, Obstruction, Neck mobility
C) Laryngoscope, Equipment, Medication, Oxygen, Neck
D) Look, Epiglottis, Mouth, Oral, Nostril
questions.rationale: LEMON predicts difficult direct laryngoscopy: Look externally, Evaluate 3-3-2 rule, Mallampati score, Obstruction, Neck mobility.

questions.stem: Which Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI) induction agent is MOST appropriate for a hemodynamically unstable patient with hypotension?
questions.rationale: Ketamine is preferred for hemodynamically unstable patients because it causes sympathetic stimulation that helps maintain blood pressure. Propofol causes significant hypotension. Etomidate causes adrenal suppression.

questions.stem: A patient develops masseter muscle rigidity and rapidly increasing temperature after succinylcholine administration. What is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.rationale: Malignant hyperthermia (Malignant Hyperthermia (MH)) is a life-threatening reaction to succinylcholine or volatile anesthetics. Classic signs include masseter rigidity, rapidly increasing temperature. Treatment is Dantrolene 2.5 mg/kg Intravenous (IV).

questions.stem: Which neuromuscular blocking agent should be AVOIDED in patients with burns greater than 24 hours old?
questions.rationale: Succinylcholine is CONTRAINDICATED in burn patients >24 hours post-injury due to upregulation of extrajunctional acetylcholine receptors causing massive potassium release and potentially fatal hyperkalemia.

questions.stem: What is the onset time for Rocuronium at standard RSI dosing (1.2 mg/kg)?
questions.rationale: Rocuronium at RSI dose (1.2 mg/kg) has onset of 45-60 seconds. At standard dosing (0.6 mg/kg), onset is 60-90 seconds.

questions.stem: Etomidate is contraindicated in which patient population?
questions.rationale: Etomidate is relatively contraindicated in septic patients because it causes adrenal suppression (inhibits 11-beta-hydroxylase) for 24-48 hours, impairing cortisol production.

questions.stem: What is the reversal agent for Rocuronium?
questions.rationale: Sugammadex (Bridion) is a specific reversal agent for rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the drug molecules. Dose is 16 mg/kg for immediate reversal.

questions.stem: Which of the following are contraindications to succinylcholine? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.rationale: Contraindications include: Malignant hyperthermia history, Burns >24 hours, Pre-existing hyperkalemia, Crush injuries. Hypotension is NOT a contraindication.

questions.stem: What is the recommended tidal volume range for mechanically ventilated patients using lung-protective strategy?
questions.rationale: Lung-protective ventilation uses tidal volumes of 6-8 mL/kg IDEAL body weight (not actual weight). For Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) patients, even lower volumes (4-6 mL/kg Ideal Body Weight (IBW)) may be used.

questions.stem: What is the normal I:E ratio on mechanical ventilation?
questions.rationale: Normal I:E ratio is 1:2, meaning expiration is twice as long as inspiration. 1:3 or greater is used for obstructive diseases (asthma/COPD).

questions.stem: A patient on the ventilator suddenly becomes hypoxic. What mnemonic is used to troubleshoot?
questions.rationale: DOPES: Displacement (of Endotracheal Tube (ETT)), Obstruction (secretions, kinking), Pneumothorax, Equipment failure, Stacking of breaths (auto-Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP)).

questions.stem: Which type of respiratory failure is characterized by hypoxemia with normal or low PaCO2?
questions.rationale: Type I (hypoxemic/hypoxic) respiratory failure is characterized by low PaO₂ with a normal or low PaCO₂ because the patient can usually ventilate (and often hyperventilates, blowing off CO₂) but cannot oxygenate due to V/Q mismatch, shunt, or diffusion impairment; classic examples include pneumonia, ARDS, pulmonary edema, and pulmonary embolism. In contrast, Type II respiratory failure is primarily a ventilation problem with elevated PaCO₂ from hypoventilation (e.g., COPD exacerbation, CNS depression, neuromuscular weakness), while Type III is a perioperative/post-op pattern driven by atelectasis that looks like hypoxemia (Type I physiology) in the surgical setting, and Type IV occurs in shock where hypoperfusion and high work of breathing lead to respiratory muscle fatigue and eventual failure. Framing it by hypoxia types, this stem describes hypoxic (hypoxemic) hypoxia (low PaO₂), whereas anemic, circulatory, and histotoxic hypoxia can all present with a normal PaO₂, so they don’t match the “hypoxemia with normal/low PaCO₂” pattern.

questions.stem: According to ARDSnet protocol, what is the target plateau pressure?
questions.rationale: ARDSnet protocol targets plateau pressure ≤30 cmH2O to prevent barotrauma. If plateau pressure exceeds 30, tidal volume should be reduced (minimum 4 mL/kg IBW).

questions.stem: What is the hallmark chest X-ray finding in ARDS?
questions.rationale: ARDS shows bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities ('white-out') on chest X-ray, representing non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

questions.stem: What Pulmonary Artery Wedge Pressure (PAWP) value helps differentiate ARDS from cardiogenic pulmonary edema?
questions.rationale: ARDS is characterized by PAWP ≤18 mmHg, indicating the pulmonary edema is NOT cardiogenic. PAWP (also known as pulmonary capillary wedge pressure or PCWP) reflects left atrial pressure and left ventricular end-diastolic pressure. Normal PAWP is 6-12 mmHg. A PAWP >18 mmHg suggests left heart failure or volume overload as the cause of pulmonary edema, rather than ARDS. This distinction is critical because treatment differs significantly: ARDS requires lung-protective ventilation and treatment of the underlying cause, while cardiogenic pulmonary edema requires diuresis and afterload reduction.

questions.stem: A 'silent chest' in a severe asthmatic indicates:
questions.rationale: A 'silent chest' in a severe asthmatic is an OMINOUS sign indicating minimal to no air movement due to severe bronchospasm. This represents imminent respiratory failure.

questions.stem: Which treatment is NOT indicated for acute hyperkalemia?
questions.rationale: Potassium chloride would WORSEN hyperkalemia and is contraindicated. Treatments include: Calcium gluconate (membrane stabilization), Sodium bicarbonate, Insulin + glucose, Albuterol, Kayexalate, Dialysis.

questions.stem: MUDPILES is the mnemonic for causes of:
options: A) Elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis
B) Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
questions.rationale: MUDPILES: Methanol, Uremia, DKA, Propylene glycol, INH/Iron, Lactic acidosis, Ethylene glycol, Salicylates - all cause elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.stem: Positive Chvostek's and Trousseau's signs indicate:
questions.rationale: Chvostek's sign (facial twitching when tapping facial nerve) and Trousseau's sign (carpopedal spasm with BP cuff inflation) are classic signs of HYPOCALCEMIA.

questions.stem: Which coagulation test measures the INTRINSIC pathway?
options: C) Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT) (Partial Thromboplastin Time)
questions.rationale: PTT measures the INTRINSIC pathway and monitors heparin therapy. PT/INR measures the EXTRINSIC pathway and monitors warfarin therapy.

questions.stem: At what lactate level is hypoperfusion/shock generally indicated?
questions.rationale: Lactate >4 mmol/L indicates significant tissue hypoperfusion and is associated with increased mortality. Normal lactate is <2 mmol/L.

questions.stem: The earliest cardiac biomarker to elevate after myocardial infarction is:
questions.rationale: Myoglobin rises within 1-4 hours of myocardial injury, making it the earliest marker. However, it's not cardiac-specific. Troponin rises in 3-6 hours and is more specific.

questions.stem: What distinguishes DKA from Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS) (HHNK)?
options: A) DKA has severe dehydration; HHS does not
B) HHS has ketoacidosis; DKA does not
C) DKA has significant ketones and acidosis; HHS has minimal ketones
D) DKA occurs only in Type 2 diabetics
questions.rationale: DKA features significant ketones, metabolic acidosis (pH <7.30), moderate hyperglycemia (300-800). HHS has severe hyperglycemia (often >600), minimal/no ketones, no significant acidosis, and profound dehydration.

questions.stem: A patient has polyuria, polydipsia, and urine specific gravity of 1.001. The most likely diagnosis is:
options: A) Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH)
questions.rationale: Diabetes Insipidus (DI) is characterized by excessive dilute urine with very LOW specific gravity (<1.005) due to lack of Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH). Treatment is Desmopressin (DDAVP) for central DI.

questions.stem: SIADH causes which electrolyte abnormality?
questions.rationale: SIADH causes HYPONATREMIA due to excessive water retention (dilutional hyponatremia). Treatment involves fluid restriction.

questions.stem: Which medication should be AVOIDED in thyroid storm?
questions.rationale: Aspirin is CONTRAINDICATED in thyroid storm because it displaces thyroid hormone from protein binding sites, increasing free T3/T4 levels. Use acetaminophen for fever.

questions.stem: A patient with known Addison's disease needs intubation. Which RSI drug should be avoided?
questions.rationale: Etomidate should be AVOIDED in Addison's disease because it inhibits 11-beta-hydroxylase, further suppressing already deficient cortisol production.

questions.stem: The medication of choice for esophageal variceal bleeding is:
questions.rationale: Octreotide reduces splanchnic blood flow and portal pressure. Dose: 50 mcg bolus then 50 mcg/hr infusion.

questions.stem: Cullen's sign and Grey-Turner's sign indicate:
questions.rationale: Cullen's sign (periumbilical ecchymosis) and Grey-Turner's sign (flank ecchymosis) indicate retroperitoneal hemorrhage, classically from hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

questions.stem: Which analgesic should be avoided in acute pancreatitis?
questions.rationale: Morphine is traditionally avoided in pancreatitis because it may cause sphincter of Oddi spasm. Fentanyl and Hydromorphone are preferred alternatives.

questions.stem: Boyle's Law states that as altitude increases:
questions.rationale: Boyle's Law: At constant temperature, gas volume is inversely proportional to pressure. As altitude increases, pressure decreases, causing gas to EXPAND. Critical for pneumothorax, ET cuff, air splints.

questions.stem: Henry's Law explains which diving-related condition?
questions.rationale: Henry's Law states that gas solubility in liquid is proportional to pressure. Rapid ascent causes nitrogen to come out of solution as bubbles, causing Decompression Sickness.

questions.stem: Decompression Sickness Type II affects which body system?
questions.rationale: Decompression Sickness (DCS) Type II involves the Central Nervous System and/or cardiopulmonary system. Symptoms include paralysis, paresthesias, confusion. Requires immediate hyperbaric oxygen.

questions.stem: Barotitis media (ear block) is most likely to occur during which phase of flight?
questions.rationale: Barotitis media occurs primarily during DESCENT when increasing atmospheric pressure compresses air in the middle ear. Management: Valsalva maneuver, decongestants.

questions.stem: Which type of hypoxia results from the body's inability to use oxygen at the cellular level?
questions.rationale: Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when cells CANNOT utilize oxygen despite adequate delivery. Classic cause is cyanide poisoning. Hypoxic = low O2 in air. Hypemic = low carrying capacity. Stagnant = poor circulation.

questions.stem: According to Federal Aviation Regulation (FAR) 91.17, what is the maximum blood alcohol concentration for flight crew members?
questions.rationale: FAR 91.17 prohibits flight crew from operating aircraft with blood alcohol ≥0.04% or within 8 hours of alcohol consumption ('8 hours bottle to throttle').

questions.stem: What transponder code indicates a hijacking?
questions.rationale: 7500 = Hijacking; 7600 = Communications failure; 7700 = Emergency/Mayday. Memory aid: '75 = taken alive, 76 = technical (radio), 77 = going to heaven.'

questions.stem: What is the NUMBER ONE cause of Emergency Medical Services (EMS) helicopter accidents?
questions.rationale: Human error is the NUMBER ONE CAUSE (~80%). Weather is the NUMBER ONE CONTRIBUTING FACTOR, but the underlying cause is the human decision to fly in adverse conditions.

questions.stem: What is the normal cardiac output range?
questions.rationale: Normal cardiac output is 4-8 L/min. Cardiac Output (CO) = Heart Rate × Stroke Volume. Cardiac Index normalizes for body size: Cardiac Index (CI) = CO/Body Surface Area (BSA), normal 2.5-4.0 L/min/m².

questions.stem: Which leads show ST elevation in an INFERIOR Myocardial Infarction (MI)?
questions.rationale: Inferior MI shows ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF. Usually caused by Right Coronary Artery (RCA) occlusion. AVOID nitroglycerin and beta-blockers if Right Ventricular (RV) involvement.

questions.stem: The delta wave on Electrocardiogram (ECG) is pathognomonic for:
questions.rationale: The delta wave (slurred upstroke of QRS) is pathognomonic for Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. AVOID Atrioventricular (AV) nodal blocking drugs in WPW with Atrial Fibrillation (AF).

questions.stem: Beck's Triad (hypotension, Jugular Venous Distension (JVD), muffled heart sounds) indicates:
questions.rationale: Beck's Triad is classic for cardiac tamponade. Additional signs: pulsus paradoxus, electrical alternans on ECG.

questions.stem: In suspected aortic dissection, which medication class should be given FIRST?
questions.rationale: Beta-blockers are given FIRST to reduce heart rate and contractility (decreasing shear stress). ONLY AFTER adequate beta-blockade can vasodilators be added.

questions.stem: At what anatomical landmark should the arterial line transducer be leveled?
options: B) Phlebostatic axis (4th Intercostal Space (ICS), midaxillary line)
questions.rationale: The transducer should be leveled at the phlebostatic axis: 4th intercostal space at the midaxillary line (level of the right atrium).

questions.stem: What is the normal range for Pulmonary Artery Wedge Pressure (PAWP)?
questions.rationale: Normal PAWP is 8-12 mmHg (some sources cite 6-12 mmHg). PAWP estimates left atrial pressure and left ventricular preload. Elevated PAWP (>18 mmHg) suggests left heart failure or volume overload. Low PAWP (<6 mmHg) suggests hypovolemia. PAWP is measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter with the balloon inflated to 'wedge' in a pulmonary artery branch.

questions.stem: The formula for Coronary Perfusion Pressure (CPP) is:
options: A) Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) - Intracranial Pressure (ICP)
questions.rationale: Coronary Perfusion Pressure = Diastolic Blood Pressure - PAWP. Coronary perfusion occurs primarily during DIASTOLE. Normal CPP is 60-80 mmHg. This is distinct from Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP = MAP - ICP).

questions.stem: In Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) therapy, the MOST dangerous timing error is:
questions.rationale: Late deflation is the MOST dangerous because the balloon is still inflated when the ventricle tries to eject, causing increased afterload and myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.stem: The IABP inflates during which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.rationale: The IABP inflates during DIASTOLE (at the dicrotic notch) to augment coronary perfusion. It deflates just before systole to reduce afterload.

questions.stem: The formula for Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) is:
questions.rationale: Cerebral Perfusion Pressure = MAP - ICP. Normal CPP is 60-100 mmHg; minimum target is >60 mmHg.

questions.stem: Cushing's Triad indicates:
questions.rationale: Cushing's Triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations) indicates severely elevated ICP with impending herniation. It's a LATE and OMINOUS sign.

questions.stem: Kernig's sign and Brudzinski's sign are indicative of:
questions.rationale: These signs indicate meningeal irritation (meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage). Kernig's = pain with knee extension when hip flexed. Brudzinski's = involuntary hip flexion with neck flexion.

questions.stem: An epidural hematoma is classically caused by injury to which vessel?
questions.rationale: Epidural hematoma is classically caused by middle meningeal artery injury. Classic presentation: trauma → 'lucid interval' → rapid deterioration. Computed Tomography (CT) shows lens-shaped hematoma.

questions.stem: Brown-Séquard syndrome results from:
options: B) Hemisection of the spinal cord
questions.rationale: Brown-Séquard syndrome results from HEMISECTION of the spinal cord. Findings: ipsilateral motor paralysis and proprioception loss, contralateral pain/temperature loss. Best prognosis of incomplete cord injuries.

questions.stem: Which medication is used to prevent vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.rationale: Nimodipine (calcium channel blocker) prevents cerebral vasospasm after Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH). Given for 21 days post-SAH. Vasospasm typically occurs 3-14 days after bleeding.

questions.stem: At what percentage of blood volume loss does hypotension typically occur?
questions.rationale: Hypotension typically occurs at 30% blood volume loss (Class III hemorrhage = 1500-2000 mL). Class I (<15%): minimal symptoms. Class II (15-30%): tachycardia.

questions.stem: Waddell's Triad is seen in pediatric patients struck by:
questions.rationale: Waddell's Triad in PEDIATRIC pedestrians: 1) Femur fracture (bumper), 2) Chest/abdominal injuries (hood), 3) Contralateral head injury (ground).

questions.stem: What is the leading cause of transfusion-related death?
questions.rationale: TRALI (Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury) is the leading cause. Presents with respiratory distress, bilateral infiltrates, hypoxemia within 6 hours of transfusion.

questions.stem: Tranexamic Acid (TXA) (Tranexamic Acid) works by:
questions.rationale: TXA INHIBITS FIBRINOLYSIS by blocking plasminogen activation. This prevents clot breakdown. Give within 3 hours of injury. Dose: 1g IV over 10 minutes, then 1g over 8 hours.

questions.stem: In massive transfusion protocol, what is the recommended ratio of Packed Red Blood Cells (PRBC):Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP):Platelets?
questions.rationale: Current protocols recommend 1:1:1 ratio, mimicking whole blood composition. This balanced approach reduces coagulopathy.

questions.stem: According to the Parkland formula, a 70 kg patient with 40% Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) burns requires how much fluid in the first 24 hours?
questions.rationale: Parkland Formula: 4 mL × kg × %TBSA = 4 × 70 × 40 = 11,200 mL. Give HALF in first 8 hours, remaining half over next 16 hours.

questions.stem: What urine output goal is targeted in electrical burn patients?
questions.rationale: Electrical burns require higher urine output targets (75-100 mL/hr) due to myoglobin release from rhabdomyolysis to prevent acute kidney injury.

questions.stem: Which type of electrical current is MORE likely to cause ventricular fibrillation?
questions.rationale: AC is MORE dangerous because it causes tetanic muscle contraction and is more likely to induce Ventricular Fibrillation (VF). DC tends to cause a single contraction and more often causes asystole.

questions.stem: The antidote for hydrofluoric acid burns is:
questions.rationale: Calcium gluconate is the specific antidote. Hydrofluoric Acid (HF) penetrates tissues and binds calcium. Apply 2.5% calcium gluconate gel topically.

questions.stem: A patient rescued from a structure fire has cherry-red skin and altered mental status. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.rationale: Cherry-red skin with altered mental status suggests CO poisoning. Oxygen Saturation (SpO2) is falsely normal. Treatment: 100% oxygen, consider hyperbaric oxygen.

questions.stem: At what core temperature does shivering typically STOP in hypothermia?
questions.rationale: Shivering typically stops at approximately 32°C (moderate hypothermia). Below this, active rewarming is required.

questions.stem: The Osborn wave (J wave) on ECG is associated with:
questions.rationale: The Osborn wave is seen in HYPOTHERMIA, typically appearing below 32°C. Size roughly correlates with degree of hypothermia.

questions.stem: The antidote for organophosphate poisoning includes:
questions.rationale: ATROPINE (blocks muscarinic effects) + PRALIDOXIME/2-PAM (reactivates acetylcholinesterase). Remember SLUDGE/DUMBELS for symptoms.

questions.stem: A patient presents with seizures, QRS widening, and hypotension after overdose. The most likely ingestion is:
questions.rationale: Tricyclic Antidepressant (TCA) overdose presents with seizures, QRS widening (>100ms), hypotension. Treatment: SODIUM BICARBONATE (1-2 mEq/kg IV, target pH 7.50-7.55).

questions.stem: High Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE) typically occurs above what altitude?
questions.rationale: HACE typically occurs above 12,000 feet. Symptoms: ataxia (hallmark), altered mental status. Treatment: immediate DESCENT, dexamethasone, oxygen.

questions.stem: Variable decelerations on fetal heart monitoring indicate:
questions.rationale: Variable decelerations indicate UMBILICAL CORD COMPRESSION. Late decelerations = uteroplacental insufficiency. Early decelerations = head compression.

questions.stem: A sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern requires:
questions.rationale: A sinusoidal pattern is OMINOUS and usually indicates severe fetal anemia. Requires IMMEDIATE DELIVERY.

questions.stem: Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets (HELLP) syndrome consists of:
options: A) Hypertension, Edema, Low platelets, Liver dysfunction, Proteinuria
B) Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets
C) High fever, Elevated lactate, Low BP, Pulmonary edema
D) Headache, Epigastric pain, Lethargy, Low Platelets
questions.rationale: HELLP: Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets. A severe variant of preeclampsia.

questions.stem: Which tocolytic works FASTEST to stop preterm contractions?
questions.rationale: Terbutaline (beta-2 agonist) has the FASTEST onset. Given as 0.25 mg subcutaneous, can work within minutes.

questions.stem: The antidote for magnesium sulfate toxicity is:
questions.rationale: CALCIUM GLUCONATE is the antidote. Mag toxicity signs: loss of DTRs (first sign), respiratory depression, cardiac arrest.

questions.stem: Painful vaginal bleeding in the third trimester is MOST consistent with:
questions.rationale: ABRUPTION = PAINFUL vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, rigid uterus. Previa = PAINLESS bleeding.

questions.stem: Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) in neonates is primarily caused by deficiency of:
questions.rationale: RDS is caused by SURFACTANT deficiency in premature infants. RDS is the #1 killer of premature infants. Treatment: exogenous surfactant.

questions.stem: A normal umbilical cord contains:
questions.rationale: Normal umbilical cord has 2 ARTERIES and 1 VEIN (remember: AVA). A single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies.

questions.stem: Treatment for a 'Tet spell' in Tetralogy of Fallot includes:
questions.rationale: Tet spell treatment: Knee-to-chest (increases Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR), reduces R-to-L shunt), Oxygen, Morphine (reduces hyperpnea), IV fluids, Phenylephrine if needed.

questions.stem: Prostaglandin E1 (Alprostadil) is used to maintain patency of what structure in ductal-dependent cardiac lesions?
questions.rationale: Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) maintains DUCTUS ARTERIOSUS patency. CRITICAL SIDE EFFECT: APNEA (up to 12%) - always be prepared to intubate.

questions.stem: The formula for calculating ETT size in children is:
questions.rationale: ETT size = (16 + Age in years) / 4, or equivalently (Age/4) + 4. For a 4-year-old: (16+4)/4 = 5.0 mm.

questions.stem: What is the formula for minimum normal systolic blood pressure in children 1-10 years?
questions.rationale: Minimum NORMAL SBP = 90 + (2 × age). HYPOTENSIVE threshold = 70 + (2 × age).

questions.stem: Initial fluid bolus for a pediatric patient in shock is:
questions.rationale: Initial fluid bolus is 20 mL/kg of isotonic crystalloid, given rapidly. May repeat up to 60 mL/kg in first hour if needed.

questions.stem: The 'steeple sign' on neck X-ray is indicative of:
questions.rationale: Steeple sign (narrowing of subglottic airway) is seen in CROUP. Treatment: steroids, nebulized racemic epinephrine if severe.

questions.stem: The 'thumbprint sign' on lateral neck X-ray suggests:
questions.rationale: Thumbprint sign (enlarged epiglottis) indicates EPIGLOTTITIS. DO NOT agitate child or examine throat - may precipitate complete obstruction.

questions.stem: SCIWORA stands for:
options: A) Spinal Cord Injury Without Obvious Radiographic Abnormality
B) Spinal Cord Ischemia Without Obvious Respiratory Arrest
C) Severe Cervical Injury With Obvious Radiologic Assessment
D) Spinal Compression Injury Without Open Reduction Attempted
questions.rationale: SCIWORA = Spinal Cord Injury Without Obvious Radiographic Abnormality. More common in children. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) needed for diagnosis.

questions.stem: What is the treatment of choice for symptomatic bradycardia unresponsive to atropine?
questions.rationale: TRANSCUTANEOUS PACING is indicated for symptomatic bradycardia unresponsive to atropine. Can also use dopamine or epinephrine infusion as bridge.

questions.stem: The treatment of choice for elevated ICP is:
questions.rationale: Mannitol (0.5-1 g/kg) or Hypertonic saline are first-line. Aggressive hyperventilation is only for imminent herniation as a bridge.

questions.stem: A patient presents with miosis, bradycardia, excessive salivation, and muscle fasciculations. This is consistent with:
questions.rationale: CHOLINERGIC toxidrome (organophosphate poisoning): SLUDGE (Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Defecation, Gastrointestinal (GI) upset, Emesis) + bradycardia, miosis, fasciculations.

questions.stem: Shoulder dystocia should be suspected when:
options: B) The fetal head delivers but retracts ('turtle sign')
D) The patient reports decreased fetal movement
questions.rationale: TURTLE SIGN (head retracts against perineum) indicates shoulder dystocia. Management: McRoberts maneuver, suprapubic pressure.

questions.stem: The preferred vascular access site for neonatal resuscitation is:
questions.rationale: UMBILICAL VEIN is preferred in neonates. It's readily accessible and can be cannulated quickly. The vein is at 12 o'clock position.

questions.stem: What is the preferred crystalloid for trauma resuscitation?
questions.rationale: LACTATED RINGER'S is preferred because it's more physiologically balanced. Large volumes of NS cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

questions.stem: Amiodarone belongs to which antiarrhythmic class?
questions.rationale: Amiodarone is primarily Class III (potassium channel blocker, prolongs repolarization/QT interval). However, it has properties of all 4 classes.

questions.stem: Which medication INCREASES systemic vascular resistance (SVR)?
questions.rationale: Norepinephrine INCREASES SVR through alpha-1 receptor stimulation. It's first-line vasopressor for septic shock.

questions.stem: Graham's Law relates to:
questions.rationale: Graham's Law: Rate of GAS DIFFUSION is inversely proportional to the square root of its molecular weight. Lighter gases diffuse faster.

questions.stem: Night vision begins to deteriorate at what altitude without supplemental oxygen?
questions.rationale: Night vision deteriorates at approximately 5,000 feet due to hypoxia. The rods in the retina are highly oxygen-dependent.

questions.stem: Permissive hypercapnia is acceptable as long as:
options: D) Plateau pressure stays below 40 cmH2O
questions.rationale: Permissive hypercapnia is acceptable as long as pH remains above 7.20. This allows lower tidal volumes to prevent volutrauma.

questions.stem: A patient with alcoholism presents with hematemesis. The MOST likely source is:
questions.rationale: In alcoholic patients, ESOPHAGEAL VARICES are most likely due to portal hypertension from cirrhosis. High mortality rate.

questions.stem: A CVP of 2 mmHg most likely indicates:
questions.rationale: Low CVP (<5 mmHg) indicates HYPOVOLEMIA (decreased preload). RHF, tamponade, and PE all cause ELEVATED CVP.

questions.stem: Which burn depth involves the epidermis only, appears red, and is painful?
questions.rationale: SUPERFICIAL burns affect epidermis only: red, dry, painful, no blisters (like sunburn). Heals in 3-7 days. NOT included in TBSA calculation.

questions.stem: Charles's Law describes the relationship between:
options: D) Molecular weight and diffusion rate
questions.rationale: Charles's Law: At constant pressure, gas volume is directly proportional to temperature. As temperature increases, volume increases.

questions.stem: The most common cause of cardiac arrest in children is:
questions.rationale: RESPIRATORY FAILURE/HYPOXIA is the most common cause of pediatric cardiac arrest. This is why pediatric BLS emphasizes airway and breathing.

questions.stem: What is the dose of Succinylcholine for RSI?
questions.rationale: Succinylcholine RSI dose is 1-1.5 mg/kg IV. Onset 30-60 seconds, duration 5-10 minutes.

questions.stem: First-degree AV block is characterized by:
questions.rationale: First-degree AV block shows prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) with 1:1 conduction. Generally benign.

questions.stem: The antidote for acetaminophen overdose is:
questions.rationale: N-ACETYLCYSTEINE (NAC) replenishes glutathione stores. Most effective if given within 8-10 hours of ingestion.

questions.stem: Amniotic fluid embolism presents with:
options: B) Respiratory distress, hypotension, and DIC
D) Chest pain and ST elevation
questions.rationale: AFE presents with sudden respiratory distress, cardiovascular collapse, altered mental status, and DIC. Mortality 60-80%.

questions.stem: In penetrating abdominal trauma, the most commonly injured solid organ is:
questions.rationale: In PENETRATING trauma, LIVER is most commonly injured due to size and location. In BLUNT trauma, SPLEEN is most common.

questions.stem: What is the initial fluid of choice for DKA treatment?
questions.rationale: Initial fluid is 0.9% NORMAL SALINE for aggressive volume resuscitation. Typical deficit is 5-10 liters. Switch to 0.45% NS later.

questions.stem: What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of a patient who opens eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and withdraws from pain?
questions.rationale: Eyes to pain = 2, Verbal incomprehensible = 2, Motor withdrawal = 4. Total = 8. GCS ≤8 indicates need for airway protection.

questions.stem: What percentage of PE patients will have a normal chest X-ray?
questions.rationale: Approximately 30-40% of PE patients have NORMAL chest X-rays. Classic findings (Hampton's hump, Westermark sign) are rare.

questions.stem: Normal Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR) is:
questions.rationale: Normal SVR is 800-1200 dynes/sec/cm⁻⁵. Low SVR occurs in septic shock, anaphylaxis. High SVR in cardiogenic shock.

questions.stem: What medication prevents intraventricular hemorrhage in premature infants?
questions.rationale: INDOMETHACIN is given prophylactically to VLBW infants to prevent IVH. Also promotes PDA closure.

questions.stem: Which electrolyte abnormality causes U waves on ECG?
questions.rationale: HYPOKALEMIA causes U waves (small wave after T wave), flattened T waves, ST depression, and predisposes to arrhythmias.

questions.stem: Pulseless electrical activity (Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA)) is treated with:
options: C) Epinephrine and identifying reversible causes
questions.rationale: PEA is treated with CPR, epinephrine, and identifying reversible causes (H's and T's). It is NOT a shockable rhythm.

questions.stem: What does PEEP stand for?
questions.rationale: PEEP = Positive End-Expiratory Pressure. It keeps alveoli open at end-expiration, improving oxygenation.

questions.stem: For needle decompression of tension pneumothorax, the preferred site is:
options: D) Both A and C are acceptable
questions.rationale: Current guidelines accept: 2nd-3rd ICS at midclavicular line OR 5th ICS at midaxillary line. Use needle at least 3.25 inches for average adults.

questions.stem: What landmark is used for cricothyrotomy?
options: A) Between thyroid and cricoid cartilage
C) At the level of the hyoid bone
D) Between first and second tracheal rings
questions.rationale: Cricothyrotomy is performed through the cricothyroid membrane, located between thyroid cartilage (Adam's apple) and cricoid cartilage.

questions.stem: Which are classic signs of Addisonian crisis? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.rationale: Addisonian crisis: Refractory hypotension, Hyperpigmentation (elevated ACTH), Hyponatremia, Hyperkalemia. Note: HYPOglycemia occurs, not hyperglycemia.

questions.stem: Murphy's sign is associated with:
questions.rationale: Murphy's sign (inspiratory arrest during RUQ palpation) is associated with cholecystitis.

questions.stem: A patient requires Fraction of Inspired Oxygen (FiO2) 0.40 at sea level. What FiO2 is needed at 8,000 feet (565 mmHg)?
At what G-force does the ELT automatically activate?
questions.rationale: The ELT automatically activates at approximately 4G or greater sustained for >11 milliseconds.

questions.stem: Sgarbossa criteria are used to identify ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) in the presence of:
questions.rationale: Sgarbossa criteria help identify STEMI in LBBB, where standard ST-segment analysis is unreliable. Score ≥3 indicates high probability of MI.

questions.stem: Electrical alternans on ECG suggests:
questions.rationale: Electrical alternans (alternating QRS amplitude) is highly suggestive of large pericardial effusion/cardiac tamponade.

questions.stem: A patient’s invasive arterial line shows an overdamped waveform (absent dicrotic notch, narrowed pulse pressure, and underestimated systolic pressure). Which of the following factors are known to cause an overdamped arterial tracing? (Select all that apply.)
options: A) Air bubbles within the arterial line tubing
B) A thrombus partially occluding the catheter tiph
C) Using an excessively long, flexible pressure tubing with multiple stopcock connectors
D) An overly stiff, short tubing system with high natural frequency (very non-compliant setup)
questions.rationale: An overdamped arterial waveform looks flattened and slurred, often with a diminished or absent dicrotic notch and a narrowed pulse pressure. It occurs when the monitoring setup absorbs too much of the pressure wave, usually because of added compliance (something compressible/elastic in the system) or added resistance/obstruction between the artery and the transducer. Common causes include air bubbles (compressible, so they cushion and blunt the waveform), partial clots/fibrin at the catheter tip (creates obstruction and dampens transmission), kinked or occluded catheter/tubing or the catheter tip resting against the vessel wall (mechanical blockage), excessively long or overly compliant tubing and extra stopcocks (increases compliance and resistance), loose connections or small leaks (introduces compliance and can allow air entry), inadequate flush bag pressure/low flush flow (promotes backflow and clot formation and reduces system performance), and sometimes arterial vasospasm around the catheter (physiologic narrowing that mimics partial obstruction).

questions.stem: A patient on the ventilator has sudden high airway pressures, absent breath sounds on the left, and tracheal deviation to the right. The diagnosis is:
questions.rationale: LEFT tension pneumothorax: absent sounds on LEFT, tracheal deviation to RIGHT (away from affected side). Requires immediate decompression.

questions.stem: A patient on heparin has a PTT of 120 seconds. The antidote is:
questions.rationale: Protamine sulfate reverses heparin. Dose: 1 mg protamine per 100 units of heparin given in past 2-3 hours.

questions.stem: Rapid correction of hyponatremia can cause:
questions.rationale: Rapid correction can cause Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (Central Pontine Myelinolysis). Maximum correction rate: 8-10 mEq/L per 24 hours.

questions.stem: Myxedema coma is a severe form of:
questions.rationale: Myxedema coma is severe HYPOTHYROIDISM with altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension. Treatment: IV levothyroxine.

questions.stem: What lactate level is part of the criteria for septic shock?
questions.rationale: Septic shock requires: sepsis PLUS vasopressor requirement to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg AND lactate >2 mmol/L. Lactate >4 indicates more severe hypoperfusion.

questions.stem: Which cardiac marker has the longest window of elevation after MI?
questions.rationale: Troponin I remains elevated for 7-14 days after MI. Myoglobin normalizes by 24 hrs. CK-MB normalizes by 48-72 hrs.

questions.stem: A COPD patient has: pH 7.38, PaCO2 58, HCO3 34. This represents:
questions.rationale: FULLY compensated respiratory acidosis. pH is normal, PaCO2 elevated (chronic COPD), HCO3 elevated (renal compensation complete).

questions.stem: Which lead is MOST sensitive for detecting ischemia?
questions.rationale: Lead V1 is most sensitive for ST-segment changes, particularly posterior MI. V1 and V5 together capture approximately 90% of ST changes.

questions.stem: What G-forces are experienced during rapid deceleration in a frontal impact?
questions.rationale: During rapid deceleration, the body experiences -Gx forces ('eyeballs out') as momentum carries the body forward.

questions.stem: What is the appropriate dose reduction for Ketamine in a hemodynamically unstable patient?
questions.rationale: In hemodynamically unstable patients, Ketamine should be reduced to 0.5-1 mg/kg (from standard 1-2 mg/kg).

questions.stem: In a patient with severe asthma, what I:E ratio adjustment should be made?
questions.rationale: In severe asthma/COPD, extend I:E ratio to 1:3, 1:4, or 1:5 to allow adequate expiration time through narrowed airways.

questions.stem: Which ventilator mode allows the patient to trigger every breath with a set pressure support?
questions.rationale: PSV is a spontaneous mode where every breath is patient-triggered and supported with a set pressure level. Used for weaning.

questions.stem: Which induction agent decreases intracranial pressure and is preferred in head-injured patients?
questions.rationale: Etomidate lowers cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen (CMRO₂—how much oxygen the brain consumes) and cerebral blood flow (CBF—the volume of blood delivered to brain tissue per unit time), which helps reduce intracranial pressure (ICP), and it usually has relatively little effect on systemic blood pressure—helping preserve cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) in head-injured patients. Ketamine was historically avoided because of concern for increasing ICP, but in sedated/ventilated severe traumatic brain injury patients it generally does not increase ICP and may lower it in selected cases, while often supporting blood pressure/CPP. Propofol also reduces CMRO₂/CBF and can reduce ICP, but it can cause vasodilation and clinically significant hypotension, which can jeopardize CPP if not carefully supported—so it’s used cautiously when blood pressure is tenuous.

questions.stem: CAMTS requires helicopter pilots to have a minimum of how many flight hours for IFR operations?
questions.rationale: CAMTS requires minimum 2,000 hours total flight time with at least 100 hours of actual or simulated instrument flight for IFR operations.

questions.stem: What does PEEP primarily improve?
questions.rationale: PEEP primarily improves OXYGENATION by keeping alveoli open at end-expiration, preventing atelectasis, and improving V/Q matching.

questions.stem: Central cord syndrome is characterized by:
options: A) Greater weakness in upper extremities than lower
B) Greater weakness in lower extremities than upper
C) Complete paralysis below the lesion
questions.rationale: Central cord syndrome affects upper extremities more than lower due to central position of upper extremity motor fibers in corticospinal tract. Often from hyperextension injury in elderly.

questions.stem: Fomepizole is the antidote for:
questions.rationale: Fomepizole inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing metabolism of methanol and ethylene glycol into toxic metabolites.

questions.stem: What is the drug of choice for stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia?
questions.rationale: Amiodarone is first-line for stable monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia (VT). Dose: 150 mg IV over 10 minutes.

questions.stem: What is permissive hypotension in trauma?
options: A) Targeting SBP 70-80 mmHg until surgical control of bleeding
B) Allowing any blood pressure level
questions.rationale: Permissive hypotension targets SBP 80-90 mmHg (or 70-80 in penetrating trauma without Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)) to avoid 'popping the clot' until definitive hemorrhage control.

questions.stem: Early decelerations on fetal monitoring indicate:
questions.rationale: Early decelerations mirror contractions and indicate FETAL HEAD COMPRESSION. They are benign and require no intervention.

questions.stem: Meconium aspiration syndrome is treated with:
options: A) Routine suctioning before delivery of shoulders
B) Intubation and suctioning of all meconium-stained infants
C) Supportive care; intubation only if infant is not vigorous
questions.rationale: Current guidelines recommend supportive care. Intubation and tracheal suctioning only if infant is NOT vigorous (poor tone, inadequate breathing, HR <100).

questions.stem: What is the correct compression depth for infant CPR?
questions.rationale: Infant compression depth is approximately 1.5 inches (4 cm), or about 1/3 of the chest depth. Rate is 100-120/min.

questions.stem: What does an elevated D-dimer indicate?
questions.rationale: Elevated D-dimer indicates clot breakdown/fibrinolysis. It's sensitive but not specific - elevated in PE, Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT), DIC, trauma, infection, pregnancy.

questions.stem: Torsades de Pointes is treated with:
questions.rationale: MAGNESIUM SULFATE is the treatment of choice for Torsades de Pointes. Dose: 1-2 g IV. If pulseless, defibrillate. Also correct underlying causes (hypokalemia, drugs that prolong QT).

questions.stem: What percentage of BSA does the palm of the patient's hand represent?
questions.rationale: The patient's palm (including fingers) represents approximately 1% of their BSA. Useful for estimating small or irregular burns.

questions.stem: The 'seatbelt sign' across the abdomen suggests injury to:
options: C) Small bowel and lumbar spine
questions.rationale: Seatbelt sign (ecchymosis across abdomen) suggests small bowel injury (especially duodenum) and lumbar spine fracture (Chance fracture).

questions.stem: Stroke Volume (SV) is calculated by:
questions.rationale: Stroke Volume = Cardiac Output / Heart Rate. Normal SV is 60-100 mL/beat. Also, CO = HR × SV.

questions.stem: Treatment for calcium channel blocker overdose includes:
questions.rationale: High-dose insulin therapy (1 unit/kg bolus, then 0.5-1 unit/kg/hr) with glucose is a key treatment for CCB overdose. Also: calcium, vasopressors, lipid emulsion for severe cases.

questions.stem: Treatment for beta-blocker overdose includes:
questions.rationale: Glucagon is the antidote for beta-blocker overdose. Dose: 5-10 mg IV bolus, then 2-5 mg/hr infusion. Bypasses blocked beta receptors.

questions.stem: Epinephrine dose for pediatric cardiac arrest is:
questions.rationale: Epinephrine dose for pediatric cardiac arrest is 0.01 mg/kg IV/Intraosseous (IO) (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration). ET dose is 0.1 mg/kg (1:1,000).

questions.stem: Initial heart rate for neonatal resuscitation should be assessed within:
questions.rationale: The 'Golden Minute' - initial steps and HR assessment should be completed within 60 seconds of birth. HR <100 = PPV. HR <60 after 30 sec PPV = compressions.

questions.stem: Umbilical cord prolapse management includes:
options: A) Immediate delivery regardless of setting
B) Elevating the presenting part off the cord until C-section
C) Clamping and cutting the cord immediately
D) Pushing the cord back into the uterus
questions.rationale: Management: Elevate presenting part (manually or position patient in knee-chest), keep cord warm and moist, emergency C-section. Never push cord back or clamp it.

questions.stem: Dalton's Law explains:
options: A) Gas volume and pressure relationship
B) Total pressure equals sum of partial pressures
questions.rationale: Dalton's Law: Total pressure of a gas mixture equals the sum of partial pressures of individual gases. Explains hypoxia at altitude as partial pressure of O2 decreases.

questions.stem: Adenosine is given for:
questions.rationale: Adenosine is first-line for stable SVT. Dose: 6 mg rapid IV push, may repeat 12 mg × 2. Causes transient AV block to break reentry circuit.

questions.stem: What rhythm shows 'saw-tooth' P waves?
questions.rationale: Atrial flutter shows characteristic 'saw-tooth' flutter waves (F waves), typically at 250-350/min with 2:1 or variable conduction to ventricles.

questions.stem: Battle's sign (mastoid ecchymosis) indicates:
questions.rationale: Battle's sign (retroauricular/mastoid ecchymosis) indicates basilar skull fracture. Also: raccoon eyes, Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea/otorrhea, hemotympanum.

questions.stem: What is the formula for Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP)?
questions.rationale: MAP = DBP + 1/3(SBP - DBP), or (SBP + 2×DBP) / 3. Normal MAP is 70-105 mmHg. Target >65 mmHg in shock states.

questions.stem: In DIC, which lab findings are expected?
options: B) Low platelets, elevated PT/PTT, low fibrinogen, elevated D-dimer
questions.rationale: DIC shows: thrombocytopenia, prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen (consumed), elevated D-dimer (clot breakdown), schistocytes on smear.

questions.stem: The antidote for digoxin toxicity is:
questions.rationale: Digoxin immune Fab (Digibind, DigiFab) binds free digoxin. Indications: life-threatening arrhythmias, hyperkalemia, ingestion >10 mg in adults.

questions.stem: tPA for stroke must be given within:
questions.rationale: IV tPA window is 3 hours (extended to 4.5 hours for select patients without certain exclusion criteria). Door-to-needle goal is <60 minutes.

questions.stem: Status epilepticus is defined as a seizure lasting longer than:
questions.rationale: Status epilepticus is now defined as seizure activity lasting >5 minutes (previously 30 minutes). First-line: benzodiazepines.

questions.stem: PEEP should be reduced in which condition?
questions.rationale: High PEEP can decrease venous return and cardiac output, worsening hypotension. In shock states, use lowest PEEP necessary.

questions.stem: Defibrillation dose for pediatric VF/pVT is:
questions.rationale: Pediatric defibrillation: 2 J/kg first shock, 4 J/kg subsequent shocks. Maximum 10 J/kg or adult dose.

questions.stem: The compression to ventilation ratio for neonatal CPR is:
questions.rationale: Neonatal CPR uses 3:1 compression to ventilation ratio (90 compressions + 30 breaths = 120 events/minute). This differs from pediatric/adult ratios.

questions.stem: McRoberts maneuver for shoulder dystocia involves:
questions.rationale: McRoberts maneuver: sharply flex maternal thighs to abdomen (hyperflexion of hips). This straightens sacrum and rotates pubic symphysis superiorly.

questions.stem: Second-degree AV block Type II (Mobitz II) is characterized by:
options: A) Progressive PR prolongation before dropped beat
B) Sudden dropped beats without PR prolongation
questions.rationale: Mobitz II: sudden dropped QRS complexes without preceding PR prolongation. More dangerous than Mobitz I, may progress to complete heart block. Often requires pacing.

questions.stem: What is the first priority in trauma assessment?
questions.rationale: Primary survey: A-B-C-D-E. Airway with cervical spine protection is always first priority in trauma. Assume C-spine injury until cleared.

questions.stem: Wernicke's encephalopathy triad includes:
options: A) Fever, neck stiffness, altered mental status
questions.rationale: Wernicke's triad: Confusion, Ataxia, Ophthalmoplegia (nystagmus, CN VI palsy). Caused by thiamine (B1) deficiency in alcoholics. Give thiamine BEFORE glucose.

questions.stem: In DKA, when should insulin infusion be started?
options: B) After initial fluid bolus and if K+ >3.3
questions.rationale: Start insulin AFTER initial fluid resuscitation and only if potassium >3.3 mEq/L. Insulin drives K+ intracellularly; giving with low K+ can cause fatal hypokalemia.

questions.stem: Rovsing's sign is associated with:
questions.rationale: Rovsing's sign: RLQ pain with palpation of LLQ (due to peritoneal irritation). Associated with appendicitis.

questions.stem: In cardiogenic shock, what hemodynamic findings are expected?
options: A) Low CO, high SVR, high PAWP
B) High CO, low SVR, low PAWP
C) Low CO, low SVR, low PAWP
D) High CO, high SVR, high PAWP
questions.rationale: Cardiogenic shock: Low cardiac output (pump failure), HIGH SVR (compensatory vasoconstriction), HIGH PAWP (backup of fluid). Cold and wet.

questions.stem: In septic shock, what hemodynamic findings are expected?
options: A) Low CO, high SVR, high PAWP
B) High CO, low SVR, low PAWP
C) Low CO, low SVR, low PAWP
D) Normal CO, normal SVR, normal PAWP
questions.rationale: Early septic shock: High cardiac output (hyperdynamic), LOW SVR (pathologic vasodilation), LOW/normal PAWP. Warm and dry initially.

questions.stem: What is the most common cause of upper airway obstruction in unconscious children?
questions.rationale: The TONGUE is the most common cause of airway obstruction in unconscious patients of any age. Position airway (head tilt-chin lift or jaw thrust).

questions.stem: Normal neonatal heart rate is:
questions.rationale: Normal neonatal heart rate is 100-160 bpm. HR <100 = begin PPV. HR <60 after 30 seconds of effective PPV = begin chest compressions.

questions.stem: Magnesium sulfate is given for:
questions.rationale: Magnesium sulfate is given for seizure prophylaxis in preeclampsia/eclampsia. Loading dose: 4-6 g IV over 20 min, then 1-2 g/hr maintenance.

questions.stem: Time of Useful Consciousness (TUC) at 35,000 feet is approximately:
questions.rationale: TUC at 35,000 feet is only 30-60 seconds. TUC decreases rapidly with altitude. At 25,000 ft: 3-5 min. At 18,000 ft: 20-30 min.

questions.stem: Which components are included in the HEAVEN criteria? (Select ALL that apply)
questions.rationale: ALL are part of HEAVEN for difficult BVM ventilation: Hypoxemia, Excess weight, Aspiration risk, Ventilation problems (asthma/COPD/pregnancy), Elderly >55, No teeth/decreased tone.

questions.stem: The H's and T's of cardiac arrest include all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: H's: Hypovolemia, Hypoxia, Hydrogen ion (acidosis), Hypo/Hyperkalemia, Hypothermia. T's: Tension pneumo, Tamponade, Toxins, Thrombosis (pulmonary/coronary). Hypoglycemia is not included.

questions.stem: Circumferential burns to extremities may require:
questions.rationale: Escharotomy (surgical incision through burned tissue) may be needed for circumferential burns causing compartment syndrome or respiratory compromise (chest burns).

questions.stem: The antidote for benzodiazepine overdose is:
questions.rationale: Flumazenil reverses benzodiazepines. Use cautiously - may precipitate seizures in chronic benzo users or mixed overdoses (especially TCAs).

questions.stem: Decorticate posturing indicates damage at what level?
questions.rationale: Decorticate (flexor) posturing: arms flexed, legs extended. Indicates damage ABOVE the red nucleus (cortical/subcortical). Decerebrate (extensor) indicates brainstem damage - worse prognosis.

questions.stem: A patient has pH 7.48, PaCO2 30, HCO3 22. This represents:
questions.rationale: Respiratory alkalosis: pH elevated (alkalotic), PaCO2 low (respiratory cause), HCO3 normal (uncompensated). Common cause: hyperventilation.

questions.stem: Thyroid storm treatment includes all EXCEPT:
questions.rationale: Aspirin is CONTRAINDICATED (displaces thyroid hormone from binding proteins). Treatment: beta-blockers, PTU/methimazole, iodine (after PTU), corticosteroids, cooling, supportive care.

questions.stem: Intraosseous access can be established in children at what site?
options: A) Proximal tibia, 1-2 cm below tibial tuberosity
questions.rationale: IO access sites include: proximal tibia (most common, 1-2 cm below tuberosity), distal tibia, distal femur (in infants), proximal humerus, and sternum (in adults).

questions.stem: What is the maximum recommended dose of Amiodarone in cardiac arrest?
questions.rationale: Amiodarone in cardiac arrest: 300 mg IV/IO first dose, may give additional 150 mg. Total maximum = 450 mg during cardiac arrest resuscitation.

questions.stem: An aircraft squawks transponder code 1200. What does this code indicate?
questions.rationale: Transponder code 1200 is used to signal Visual Flight Rules (VFR) code. The other choices are standard codes for different situations (e.g., hijack, communications failure, or general VFR), so choosing the wrong one can miscommunicate the urgency and nature of the event.

questions.stem: An aircraft squawks transponder code 7500. What does this code indicate?
questions.rationale: Transponder code 7500 is used to signal Hijack. The other choices are standard codes for different situations (e.g., hijack, communications failure, or general VFR), so choosing the wrong one can miscommunicate the urgency and nature of the event.

questions.stem: An aircraft squawks transponder code 7600. What does this code indicate?
questions.rationale: Transponder code 7600 is used to signal Communications failure. The other choices are standard codes for different situations (e.g., hijack, communications failure, or general VFR), so choosing the wrong one can miscommunicate the urgency and nature of the event.

questions.stem: An aircraft squawks transponder code 7700. What does this code indicate?
questions.rationale: Transponder code 7700 is used to signal Emergency. The other choices are standard codes for different situations (e.g., hijack, communications failure, or general VFR), so choosing the wrong one can miscommunicate the urgency and nature of the event.

questions.stem: An aircraft squawks transponder code 7777. What does this code indicate?
questions.rationale: Transponder code 7777 is used to signal Military intercept code. The other choices are standard codes for different situations (e.g., hijack, communications failure, or general VFR), so choosing the wrong one can miscommunicate the urgency and nature of the event.

questions.stem: A hasty/unsecured helicopter landing zone (HLZ) should generally be at least what size to support safe landing operations?
questions.rationale: A commonly taught minimum for a hasty HLZ is about 100' x 100'. Smaller zones increase rotor/obstacle strike risk and make hazard identification harder; much larger zones may be needed depending on aircraft type, wind, slope, and obstacles.

questions.stem: Which actions are appropriate during HLZ setup for a hasty/unsecured HLZ? (Select all that apply.)
options: A) Ensure communication with the ground/LZ coordinator
B) Use a single approach and departure heading for planning
C) Perform two passes prior to landing (one high, one low) to identify hazards
D) Mark the HLZ at night by having two vehicles cross their headlight beams
questions.rationale: Safe HLZ operations emphasize communication, hazard reconnaissance, and clear markings. Two reconnaissance passes help identify wires/obstacles. Standing under the rotor disk is unsafe; ground personnel should remain clear of rotor arc and follow the pilot-in-command (PIC) direction.

questions.stem: When approaching a helicopter on the ground (when directed by the pilot-in-command), which approach direction is generally recommended?
options: A) From the 11 o'clock or 1 o'clock position
B) From the 6 o'clock position (directly from the rear)
C) From any direction as long as you stay low
D) From the 3 o'clock position (directly from the side)
questions.rationale: Approach is typically from forward quadrants (around 11 or 1 o'clock) to stay within the pilot’s field of view and away from the tail rotor. Approaching from the rear increases the risk of tail rotor strike and reduces the pilot’s ability to see you.

questions.stem: A patient is being loaded for flight. Which securing practices are recommended? (Select all that apply.)
options: A) Use three cross straps (chest, hips, and knees)
B) Position the patient's head forward when feasible
C) Pad voids to reduce movement
D) Leave shoulder harness off to allow easier access
questions.rationale: In rotor- or fixed-wing transport, patient and equipment restraint prevents secondary injury during turbulence or abrupt maneuvering. Three cross straps plus a shoulder harness (as tolerated) and padding voids reduce shear and fall risk. Leaving restraints off increases hazard during even minor movement.

questions.stem: In Air Medical Resource Management (AMRM), which statement best reflects the crew decision-making principle?
options: A) All crew members must agree to proceed; any one member can call for a stop
B) Only the pilot may decide to abort a mission
C) Medical crew decisions override pilot authority
D) Proceed unless there is a written policy prohibiting it
questions.rationale: AMRM is an adaptation of crew resource management that supports safety culture: “all to go, one to say no.” While the PIC retains ultimate authority, AMRM encourages speaking up early and stopping when any crew member identifies a safety threat.

questions.stem: When is a 'sterile cockpit' commonly implemented in air medical operations? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Sterile cockpit periods reduce nonessential conversation/distraction during high-workload and high-risk phases (taxi, takeoff, landing, refueling). It's not limited to a specific altitude; it’s about task loading and risk.

questions.stem: Per a typical emergency action plan (EAP) trigger, the plan is activated after which event?
options: A) Two missed checks or 30 minutes after the last check
C) After landing at the destination
D) Only after confirmation of an accident by authorities
questions.rationale: An EAP is designed to start early when an aircraft is overdue or contact is lost. A common trigger is two missed check-ins or 30 minutes after the last check, prompting escalation before delays become life-threatening.

questions.stem: A flight crew member asks about 'bottle to throttle' time under FAR 91. What is commonly taught as the minimum time between alcohol consumption and flying duties?
questions.rationale: Under FAR 91, a commonly taught minimum is 8 hours (“bottle to throttle”). Many programs also use stricter policies based on impairment risk; the key exam concept is recognizing regulatory minimums vs. more conservative organizational standards.

questions.stem: A day flight is being considered. What weather minimums are commonly cited for a day flight?
options: A) 800 ft ceiling and 2 miles visibility
B) 500 ft ceiling and 1 mile visibility
C) 1,500 ft ceiling and 5 miles visibility
D) No minimums for day flight
questions.rationale: day weather minimums are taught as 800 ft ceiling and 2 miles visibility, while night minimums are more restrictive. Weather minimums reduce controlled flight into terrain risk and preserve route/landing options.

questions.stem: A night flight is being considered. What weather minimums are commonly cited for a night flight?
options: A) 800 ft ceiling and 3 miles visibility
B) 800 ft ceiling and 1 mile visibility
C) 500 ft ceiling and 2 miles visibility
D) 1,000 ft ceiling and 2 miles visibility
questions.rationale: night weather minimums are taught as 800 ft ceiling and 3 miles visibility, reflecting the increased risk of obstacle collision and spatial disorientation when visual cues are limited.

questions.stem: According to CAMTS-style ground operations standards, a ground ambulance should be capable of traveling at least what distance without refueling (minimum range)?
questions.rationale: A commonly cited CAMTS operational benchmark is a 175-mile range. The intent is to maintain operational readiness and reduce mission failure from insufficient fuel capacity.

questions.stem: According to CAMTS-style ground operations standards, minimum ground clearance at gross ambulance weight should be approximately:
questions.rationale: A typical CAMTS benchmark is ~6 inches of ground clearance when loaded, helping reduce undercarriage damage and mobility issues (e.g., ramps, uneven terrain) that can compromise safety.

questions.stem: According to CAMTS-style ground operations standards, sirens should be audible under normal conditions from at least:
questions.rationale: A common CAMTS benchmark is that the siren should be audible at greater than 500 feet. This supports earlier warning to traffic, though crews should remember that at highway speeds you can still 'outrun your siren.'

questions.stem: What is commonly described as the most dangerous location for a ground ambulance during emergency driving?
questions.rationale: Intersections combine crossing traffic, unpredictable driver behavior, and reduced reaction time—making intersections the highest-risk area. Defensive driving and controlled intersection clearing are key safety practices.

questions.stem: Which duties are commonly assigned to a surface vehicle co-pilot during transport operations? (Select all that apply.)
options: A) Navigation and verifying GPS input
B) Managing lights and sirens response
D) Performing nonessential cell phone/computer use
questions.rationale: A co-pilot supports safe transport by handling navigation, warning device operations, and crew risk monitoring (fatigue/impairment). Nonessential phone/computer use is typically prohibited because it increases distraction risk.

questions.stem: Which altitude range is commonly described as the 'physiologically deficient zone'?
questions.rationale: The physiologically deficient zone (10k–50k ft) is where hypoxia becomes increasingly dangerous and supplemental oxygen may be required. Below 10,000 ft is generally considered the physiologic zone; above 50,000 ft is often described as 'space-equivalent' in training materials.

questions.stem: Approximately how much does Partial Pressure of Arterial Oxygen (PaO2) drop for each 1,000-foot increase in altitude (as taught )?
options: D) It remains constant until 18,000 feet
questions.rationale: A commonly taught rule of thumb is ~5 mmHg PaO2 drop per 1,000 ft. This highlights why patients with marginal oxygenation at sea level can deteriorate quickly with ascent.

questions.stem: Oxygen is required above 10,000 feet for any time greater than approximately how many minutes (as taught )?
questions.rationale: supplemental oxygen is taught as required above 10,000 ft for >10 minutes, reflecting the progressive hypoxia risk with continued exposure.

questions.stem: A patient is transported in an unpressurized aircraft. What is a commonly taught atmospheric pressure at sea level?
questions.rationale: Sea-level barometric pressure is commonly taught as 760 mmHg (torr). Lower pressures (e.g., 523 mmHg, 380 mmHg) correspond to higher altitudes.

questions.stem: the atmospheric pressure at approximately 18,000 feet is:
questions.rationale: Training materials often reference ~380 torr at 18,000 ft, roughly half of sea-level pressure. Lower ambient pressure drives gas expansion (Boyle’s law) and worsens hypoxia (lower inspired PO2).

questions.stem: A rapid loss of cabin pressure occurs at 30,000 feet. What is the commonly taught Time of Useful Consciousness (TUC) for rapid decompression at this altitude?
questions.rationale: At 30,000 ft, rapid decompression dramatically shortens TUC—commonly taught as ~45 seconds—because oxygen reserve and inspired partial pressure drop abruptly. Slower decompression can allow longer effective performance time, but action must still be immediate.

questions.stem: A gradual decompression occurs at 30,000 feet. What is the commonly taught TUC for slower decompression at this altitude?
questions.rationale: At 30,000 ft, slower decompression is commonly taught as giving ~90 seconds of useful consciousness. Even this short window requires rapid oxygen application and descent planning.

questions.stem: Barodontalgia (tooth pain) is primarily associated with which phase of flight?
questions.rationale: Barodontalgia is typically associated with ascent because trapped gas in dental spaces expands with decreasing ambient pressure, producing pain. Descent more commonly causes middle ear or sinus barotrauma when gas cannot equalize.

questions.stem: Barotitis media (middle ear barotrauma) is primarily associated with which phase of flight?
questions.rationale: Middle ear barotrauma is commonly linked to descent because increasing ambient pressure requires active equalization via the Eustachian tube; blockage traps relative negative pressure in the middle ear, causing pain and injury.

questions.stem: Barosinusitis (sinus barotrauma) is primarily associated with which phase of flight?
questions.rationale: Sinus barotrauma is commonly taught as a descent problem: increasing ambient pressure requires sinus venting; obstruction prevents equalization, producing mucosal injury and pain.

questions.stem: Which gas law is most commonly associated with decompression sickness due to nitrogen coming out of solution as pressure decreases?
questions.rationale: Decompression sickness involves dissolved gases (primarily nitrogen) coming out of solution as ambient pressure decreases—this is described by Henry’s law. Boyle’s law describes gas volume expansion; Dalton’s law describes partial pressures.

questions.stem: Which hypoxia stages are described as altitude increases? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Training frameworks often describe progressive hypoxia stages: Indifference, Compensatory, Disturbance, and Critical. Recognizing the stage helps anticipate cognitive/coordination decline and the need for immediate oxygen and descent.

questions.stem: Which gravitational force direction is generally considered best tolerated by humans in aviation physiology training?
questions.rationale: Humans generally tolerate Gx (anterior–posterior) better than sustained head-to-foot (Gz) loading, which promotes blood pooling and reduced cerebral perfusion. Tolerance depends on magnitude, duration, and restraint/positioning.

questions.stem: For every 1,000-foot increase in altitude, temperature is commonly taught to decrease by approximately:
questions.rationale: A common aviation rule of thumb is temperature decreases ~2° per 1,000 ft (rate varies by conditions). Cooler temperatures can worsen hypothermia risk in exposed patients and affect equipment performance.

questions.stem: Which formula best represents a commonly taught method to adjust FiO2 for a change in atmospheric pressure with altitude?
options: A) (Current FiO2 x P1) / P2 = new FiO2
B) (Current FiO2 x P2) / P1 = new FiO2
C) FiO2 does not change with altitude
D) FiO2 should always be set to 1.0 at altitude
questions.rationale: A common teaching tool uses (FiO2 x current pressure) / expected pressure to estimate the FiO2 needed to maintain a similar inspired oxygen partial pressure. It’s a conceptual aid; in practice, you titrate to clinical targets (SpO2/PaO2).

questions.stem: Which findings are taught as indications for advanced airway management/intubation? (Select all that apply.)
options: D) Patient unable to protect their airway
questions.rationale: Indications focus on inability to oxygenate/ventilate or protect the airway, and anticipated deterioration (e.g., inhalation injury). A GCS of <8 is not an imediate indicatioin for intubation.

questions.stem: which ABG value alone may indicate the possible need for intubation due to respiratory failure?
questions.rationale: A PaO2 < 60 mmHg reflects significant hypoxemia. any single critical ABG abnormality (e.g., low pH, high CO2, low PaO2) can support the decision to intubate when paired with clinical failure to oxygenate/ventilate.

questions.stem: Which ventilator pressure best reflects alveolar pressure and is commonly considered the most important pressure to monitor for lung injury risk?
questions.rationale: Plateau pressure (Pplat) approximates alveolar pressure during an inspiratory hold, making it a key marker of overdistension risk. PIP is influenced by airway resistance (tube/circuit/bronchospasm) and may overestimate alveolar stress.

questions.stem: A ventilated patient has PIP 48 cm H2O and Pplat 18 cm H2O. What is the most likely problem category?
options: A) Increased airway resistance/upper airway issue
C) Pulmonary edema causing stiff lungs
questions.rationale: A high PIP with normal Pplat suggests resistance problems (kinked tube, biting, secretions, bronchospasm, circuit obstruction). If both PIP and Pplat rise, compliance/alveolar issues (ARDS, edema, tension pneumothorax) are more likely.

questions.stem: A trauma patient on volume control has PIP 48 cm H2O and Pplat 38 cm H2O with sudden deterioration. Which cause and immediate action are most consistent with this pattern?
options: A) Tension pneumothorax; perform immediate needle decompression
B) Kinked suction catheter; remove and continue ventilation
C) ETT too small; increase tidal volume
D) Low PEEP; turn PEEP to zero
questions.rationale: When both PIP and Pplat are elevated, compliance is reduced and alveolar pressure is high. In a trauma patient with sudden decline, tension pneumothorax is a high‑risk, time‑critical cause—needle decompression is the rapid lifesaving intervention.

questions.stem: A non-trauma patient has PIP 48 cm H2O and Pplat 38 cm H2O. Which explanation is most consistent with this pattern?
options: A) Fluid/pressure limiting lung expansion (e.g., pulmonary edema, ascites, compartment syndrome)
B) Primary airway resistance from a kinked tube
D) Increased patient drive with normal lung mechanics
questions.rationale: If PIP and Pplat rise together, the issue is typically reduced compliance (stiffer lungs or external compression). Non-trauma causes include pulmonary edema, ARDS, ascites, or abdominal compartment syndrome—conditions that increase alveolar pressure for a given tidal volume.

questions.stem: plateau pressure should generally be kept below which threshold to reduce barotrauma risk?
questions.rationale: A commonly taught lung-protective target is Pplat < 30 cm H2O, because higher plateau pressures correlate with overdistension/ventilator-induced lung injury. PIP targets can be higher and are less specific for alveolar stress.

questions.stem: peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) is commonly targeted to remain below:
questions.rationale: PIP is often targeted < 40 cm H2O as a general safety threshold. Because PIP reflects resistance plus compliance, it is less specific than plateau pressure for alveolar overdistension but still useful as an alarm/monitoring parameter.

questions.stem: Which factors can increase plateau pressure (Pplat) in a ventilated patient? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Pplat rises with decreased compliance or increased distending volume: ARDS, edema, tension pneumothorax, higher tidal volumes, and external compression (Trendelenburg, obesity, pregnancy, ascites). Circuit kinks primarily increase PIP (resistance), not plateau pressure.

questions.stem: If Pplat is elevated which ventilator adjustment sequence is most consistent with a lung-protective approach?
options: A) Reduce tidal volume in small steps and reassess; consider switching from volume to pressure delivery if needed
B) Increase tidal volume to improve ventilation regardless of pressures
C) Increase inspiratory flow to raise plateau pressure intentionally
D) Eliminate PEEP completely in all cases
questions.rationale: A lung-protective strategy prioritizes limiting alveolar overdistension. If plateau pressure is high, first correct reversible causes (positioning, pneumothorax, abdominal distension) and decrease tidal volume stepwise, reassessing plateau. If pressures remain high, switching delivery mode may help.

questions.stem: Which ventilator setting primarily applies only to spontaneous breaths and provides a pressure 'boost' when the patient initiates a breath?
questions.rationale: Pressure support is applied to spontaneous breaths to overcome circuit/ETT resistance and reduce work of breathing. It is not the same as PEEP (baseline pressure) or a set tidal volume (volume-controlled target).

questions.stem: a typical starting pressure support level is approximately:
questions.rationale: A commonly taught starting PS is ~10 cm H2O, then titrated based on tidal volumes, work of breathing, synchrony, and gas exchange. Too much support can reduce respiratory drive and delay liberation.

questions.stem: In pressure support ventilation, if spontaneous tidal volume exceeds ~75% of the set/target tidal volume what is an appropriate action?
options: A) Increase trigger sensitivity, deepen sedation if needed, and/or decrease PS by small increments
B) Increase PS substantially to further raise tidal volume
C) Turn PEEP to zero immediately
questions.rationale: Excessive spontaneous tidal volumes under PS may indicate over-assistance or dyssynchrony. The framework recommends optimizing trigger sensitivity, ensuring adequate sedation/comfort, and reducing PS gradually to avoid volutrauma and improve synchrony.

questions.stem: High FiO2 can contribute to absorptive atelectasis primarily by which mechanism?
options: A) Nitrogen washout reduces 'alveolar stenting,' increasing collapse risk unless PEEP is maintained
B) Oxygen directly paralyzes surfactant production in all patients
C) FiO2 increases airway resistance immediately
D) High FiO2 always prevents atelectasis regardless of PEEP
questions.rationale: Nitrogen helps maintain alveolar volume because it is poorly absorbed; high FiO2 washes out nitrogen, allowing alveoli to collapse as oxygen diffuses into blood. PEEP helps maintain alveolar recruitment and reduces this collapse risk.

questions.stem: For obstructive lung disease ventilation strategy which respiratory rate and I:E ratio are most appropriate?
questions.rationale: Obstructive disease management emphasizes long expiratory time to limit air trapping/auto‑PEEP: lower RR (10–12) and prolonged exhalation (I:E 1:4–1:5). Higher RR shortens exhalation and worsens dynamic hyperinflation.

questions.stem: Which components are included in the LEMON difficult airway assessment mnemonic? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: LEMON summarizes bedside predictors of difficult laryngoscopy: Look, Evaluate 3‑3‑2, Mallampati, Obstruction/Obesity, and Neck mobility. It helps teams anticipate adjuncts, positioning, and backup plans.

questions.stem: For pediatric ETT sizing, this question bank uses an age-based calculation of:
questions.rationale: An age-based estimate taught here is (16 − age)/4 (framework-specific). Pediatric sizing should be confirmed with clinical fit/leak and local protocols; having multiple tube sizes ready is standard.

questions.stem: Needle cricothyrotomy is taught to be performed in which pediatric age group?
questions.rationale: needle cricothyrotomy is recommended for children under 8 because surgical cric anatomy is small and higher-risk. Age cutoffs vary by system; the exam concept is choosing a front-of-neck option appropriate to pediatric anatomy.

questions.stem: The Pediatric Assessment Triangle (PAT) evaluates which three domains? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: PAT is a rapid visual assessment of Appearance, Work of breathing, and Circulation to skin. It is designed for quick severity assessment before detailed vitals and directs urgency and immediate interventions.

questions.stem: Which are the three key anatomical landmarks emphasized for direct laryngoscopy/intubation?
options: A) Epiglottis, vallecula, true vocal cords
C) Soft palate, hard palate, gums
questions.rationale: Direct laryngoscopy focuses on identifying the epiglottis, placing the blade in the vallecula (with Macintosh technique), and visualizing the true vocal cords for tube passage. Missing these landmarks increases esophageal placement risk.

questions.stem: Which step occurs first in the intubation sequence described?
options: A) Place the patient in the sniffing position
D) Advance the tube 2–3 cm after passing the cords
questions.rationale: Positioning (sniffing) aligns oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes and improves glottic view. Tube advancement, cuff inflation, confirmation (ETCO2/auscultation), and securing occur later.

questions.stem: After intubation, which steps are part of confirmation and securing in the sequence described? (Select all that apply.)
options: D) Deflate cuff to reduce pressure
